The law also makes changes to the way the government borrows money and manages its debt. series.short: "Tackling Abusive Tax Arrangements: Introducing the General Anti-Abuse Rule"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The General Anti-Abuse Rule (GAAR) is introduced to counteract tax advantages arising from abusive tax arrangements.
* Simplified point 2: Tax arrangements are considered abusive if they do not align with the principles of the relevant tax provisions or policies, or if they involve contrived or unusual steps.
* Simplified point 3: The GAAR applies to various taxes, including income tax, corporation tax, capital gains tax, petroleum revenue tax, inheritance tax, stamp duty land tax, and annual tax on enveloped dwellings.
* Simplified point 4: The GAAR allows for adjustments to be made to counteract tax advantages, and these adjustments may be made up to 12 months after the counteraction becomes final.
* Simplified point 5: Consequential adjustments may be made to refund overpaid tax or to recover unpaid tax, and these adjustments may be made up to 12 months after the counteraction becomes final.
* Simplified point 6: The GAAR takes precedence over any priority rules, and any priority rules must be read subject to the GAAR.

* Simplified point 5: Orders made under the Finance Act 2013 can take effect from the start of the tax year in which they are made, and can include transitional provisions to help smooth the transition to the new residence test.
